    Highlighting and dplyr

Highlighting and dplyr

Source: vignettes/highlighting-and-dplyr.Rmd
highlighting-and-dplyr.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette describes some functions which are designed for working with highlighted vectors as columns in a data.frame or tibble and provides some examples of manipulating highlights using dplyr functions.

library(vlightr)
library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)

Before we begin, let’s define a new formatter function emph() which adds a prefix left and a suffix right to the text x and colors the text background the color col. If you are reading this vignette in R (say within the RStudio Help pane) then you likely won’t be able to see the background color col.

emph <- function(x, col = "bright_yellow", left = "[ ", right = " ]") {
  background_fun <- background(col)
  background_fun(paste0(left, x, right))
}

# Test it out
emph("Hello", "bright_green", "<", ">")
#> <cli_ansi_string>
#> [1] <Hello>

Using dplyr::across(), a word of warning

This section documents a confusing error which can arise from using highlight_case() within dplyr::across().

If you’re here because you encountered such an error, the short story is that the across() formula syntax .fns = ~ f(.x) is incompatible with highlight_case() and friends.

Consider the case where we want to color all NA values blue in the starwars tibble. The example below shows the what works and what will cause an error. The rest of this section goes into detail about what is causing the problem.

starwars %>%
  mutate(
    across(
      # Using `\()` or `function()` will work
      .cols = where(is_highlightable),
      .fns = \(col) highlight_case(col, is.na(.x) ~ color("blue")(.x))
    
      # Using `~` will raise an error
      # .fns = ~ highlight_case(.x, is.na(.x) ~ color("blue")(.x))
    )
  )

Incorrect output length

vlightr follows the lead of packages across the tidyverse (most notably purrr), which use the symbol .x to represent an argument to an anonymous (AKA lambda) function, e.g. ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE) in place of \(x) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE). While this can make vlightr lambdas more familiar to some R users, the symbol .x being such a hot commodity does introduce a conflict between dplyr::across() and highlight_case() (as well as vlightr’s other *_case() functions).

Consider the earlier example, where we highlighted the row of any Star Wars character which is a Droid. With a small change to the across() call, we are faced with a lengthy chained error message.

try(
  starwars %>%
  mutate(
    across(
      where(is_highlightable),
      # Before: \(col) templight_case(col, species == "Droid" ~ emph(.x))
      ~templight_case(.x, species == "Droid" ~ emph(.x))
    )
  )
)
#> Error in mutate(., across(where(is_highlightable), ~templight_case(.x,  : 
#>   ℹ In argument: `across(...)`.
#> Caused by error in `across()`:
#> ! Can't compute column `name`.
#> Caused by error in `highlight()`:
#> ! Attempted to create a <highlight<character>> vector with a malformed
#>   `format()` method.
#> Caused by error in `format()`:
#> ! Formatter `attr(,"formatters")[[1]]()` must produce an output of the
#>   same length of it's input.
#> ℹ `attr(,"formatters")[[1]]()` recieved a length 6 input.
#> ℹ `attr(,"formatters")[[1]]()` produced a length 87 output.
#> ℹ Did you highlight a vector using a formula (`.fns = ~...`) in
#>   `dplyr::across()`?
#> • vlightr `*_case()` functions are incompatible with this syntax.
#>   # Good
#>   dplyr::across(x, \(col) highlight_case(col, is.na(.x) ~ color("red")(.x)))
#>   # Bad
#>   dplyr::across(x, ~highlight_case(.x, is.na(.x) ~ color("red")(.x)))

Reading the end of the message, we see that first formatter attr(,"formatters")[[1]], defined by emph(.x), returned a length 87 result (the number of rows in starwars) when it should have returned a length 6 result (the number of Droids listed in starwars), causing an error.

This happens because, when a formula lambda (e.g. ~templight_case(...)) is used within across(), the placeholder symbol .x is replaced (usually) with the name of the current column.

For instance, when name, the first column in starwars, is mutated by the call to across(), the expression species == "Droid" ~ emph(.x) is substituted with the expression species == "Droid" ~ emph(name).

When templight_case() converts the right-hand-side of this formula into a formatter function, it will look like function(.x) emph(name). This formatter will always be in terms of the column name, rather than in terms of the argument .x.

Consequently, when the column name is conditionally formatted, the formatter function receives the names of 6 Droids to highlight yellow, but outputs emph(name) instead, a length 87 vector of every character name in the starwars dataset. This is what causes the length error.

We can remedy this error in a several ways:

starwars %>%
  mutate(
    across(
      where(is_highlightable),
      # This works:
      \(col) templight_case(col, species == "Droid" ~ emph(.x))
      
      # These also work:
      # ~ templight_case(.x, species == "Droid" ~ \(x) emph(x))
      # ~ templight(.x, species == "Droid", ~ emph(.x))
    )
  ) %>%
  select(1:4) %>%
  head()
#> # A tibble: 6 × 4
#>             name       height         mass   hair_color
#>     <hlght<chr>> <hlght<int>> <hlght<dbl>> <hlght<chr>>
#> 1 Luke Skywalker          172           77        blond
#> 2      [ C-3PO ]      [ 167 ]       [ 75 ]       [ NA ]
#> 3      [ R2-D2 ]       [ 96 ]       [ 32 ]       [ NA ]
#> 4    Darth Vader          202          136         none
#> 5    Leia Organa          150           49        brown
#> 6      Owen Lars          178          120  brown, grey

Obsolete data mask

A second, even more confusing error, occurs when the formatters supplied to templight_case() produces a result of the correct length. Instead of highlighting only droids, let’s see what happens when we attempt to highlight every column and row.

try(
  starwars %>%
    mutate(
      across(
        where(is_highlightable),
        ~templight_case(.x, TRUE ~ emph(.x))
      )
    ) %>%
    format()
)
#> Error in format(x) : 
#>   Highlighted vector has a malformed `format()` method.
#> Caused by error in `attr(,"formatters")[[1]]`:
#> ! Obsolete data mask.
#> ✖ Too late to resolve `name` after the end of `dplyr::mutate()`.
#> ℹ Did you save an object that uses `name` lazily in a column in the
#>   `dplyr::mutate()` expression ?

Just like in the previous example, templight_case() has created the formatter function function(.x) emph(name) in terms of the column name, instead of in terms of .x. Unlike in the previous example, because we’re highlighting every row in starwars, this formatter will return a vector of the correct length (i.e. equal to nrow(starwars)) when the highlighted vector is created within across().

When the highlighted starwars tibble is formatted or printed, however, the column name no longer exists in the environment of the formatter function function(.x) emph(name) and thus can’t be evaluated, causing the obsolete data mask error.

As before, we just need to replace the ~ with \() to resolve the issue.

starwars %>%
  mutate(
    across(
      where(is_highlightable),
      \(col) templight_case(col, TRUE ~ emph(.x))
    )
  ) %>%
  select(1:4) %>%
  head()
#> # A tibble: 6 × 4
#>                 name       height         mass      hair_color
#>         <hlght<chr>> <hlght<int>> <hlght<dbl>>    <hlght<chr>>
#> 1 [ Luke Skywalker ]      [ 172 ]       [ 77 ]       [ blond ]
#> 2          [ C-3PO ]      [ 167 ]       [ 75 ]          [ NA ]
#> 3          [ R2-D2 ]       [ 96 ]       [ 32 ]          [ NA ]
#> 4    [ Darth Vader ]      [ 202 ]      [ 136 ]        [ none ]
#> 5    [ Leia Organa ]      [ 150 ]       [ 49 ]       [ brown ]
#> 6      [ Owen Lars ]      [ 178 ]      [ 120 ] [ brown, grey ]
